articles.title: Mexico City: Create Care Law Grounded on Disability Rights
articles.summary:

They are rights holders, with expertise grounded in lived experience, and their proposals deserve serious consideration.”The coalition submitted its proposal as the Mexico City Congress moves from pre-consultations toward drafting formal care and support legislation. Members urged lawmakers to seize the opportunity to build a care and support system that expands choice, autonomy, and inclusion, in line with Advisory Opinion 31/2025 of the Inter-American Court of Human Rights and the Tlatelolco Commitment, a regional agreement.The proposal seeks to shift the focus of Mexico City’s care and support system away from narrow, charity-based approaches and toward a comprehensive, rights-based framework aligned with international human rights law, Human Rights Watch said. It outlines a broad range of support that people with disabilities may require to exercise their rights on an equal basis with others. These include support to access information, exercise legal capacity, prevent and report violence, ensure personal mobility, participate in education and employment, and engage fully in community and public life.The proposal also emphasizes the central role of personal assistance and community-based services, such as centers for independent living, to prevent institutionalization and forced dependence on families.Diana Velarde, executive director of Mexicanas con Discapacidad and a member of the coalition, said the proposal reflects what people with disabilities have long demanded in their daily lives. “For many of us, support is not an abstract legal concept—it is what makes it possible to leave our homes, participate in our communities, and live with dignity,” Velarde said. “This proposal puts into law what international standards already recognize: that care and support are rights, and that states have an obligation to ensure they are available, accessible, and centered on people’s autonomy.”Coalition members also emphasized the often invisible costs of relying on unpaid family care and support. Sara Villanueva, a member of the coalition who requires intensive support, said the absence of adequate public systems places an unsustainable responsibility on families, particularly as the parents of people with disabilities grow older.“In many cases, the support that allows us to live day to day is provided by our families, without pay, without rest, and without alternatives,” Villanueva said. “My parents—both in their 80s—continue to provide essential support so that I can live my life. This is not a solution that can last forever.”Villanueva emphasized that the proposal is especially significant because it reflects the realities of people with disabilities themselves. “This coalition is made up almost entirely of people with disabilities, most of us women,” she said. “Our proposal responds to real needs and real barriers, not assumptions about our lives.”“Aligning care and support policies with international human rights standards is both possible and effective to ensure rights for care and support providers and people with disabilities,” Ríos Espinosa said. “Mexico City has an opportunity to ensure that its legislative proposals on care and support are consistent with these standards and recognize supports for independent living as a core component of equality and dignity for people with disabilities.”
articles.content:
Click to expand Image Participants in the International Day of Persons with Disabilities demonstration in Mexico City, 2022. © 2022 Human Rights Watch

(Mexico City) – The Mexico City Congress should seriously consider a proposal submitted by a coalition led by people with disabilities during its new session, Human Rights Watch said today. That proposal urges lawmakers to adopt a rights-based framework grounded in autonomy, participation, and independent living for care and support legislation.

The Coalition, Cuidados Sí; Apoyos También (Care Yes; Supports Too), is made up largely of people with disabilities. It includes organizations such as Mexicanas con Discapacidad, Women Enabled International, Movimiento de Personas con Discapacidad as well as human rights organizations including Yo También, Human Rights Watch, and Documenta. The coalition has submitted a proposal calling on legislators to include a dedicated chapter on support for independent living in the care and support bills currently under review by the Congress of Mexico City.

“Care and support policies developed without the meaningful participation of the people who will rely on them risk reinforcing the very dependence and exclusion they are meant to address,” said Carlos Ríos Espinosa, associate disability rights director at Human Rights Watch. “People with disabilities are not passive recipients of care and support. They are rights holders, with expertise grounded in lived experience, and their proposals deserve serious consideration.”

The coalition submitted its proposal as the Mexico City Congress moves from pre-consultations toward drafting formal care and support legislation. Members urged lawmakers to seize the opportunity to build a care and support system that expands choice, autonomy, and inclusion, in line with Advisory Opinion 31/2025 of the Inter-American Court of Human Rights and the Tlatelolco Commitment, a regional agreement.

The proposal seeks to shift the focus of Mexico City’s care and support system away from narrow, charity-based approaches and toward a comprehensive, rights-based framework aligned with international human rights law, Human Rights Watch said. It outlines a broad range of support that people with disabilities may require to exercise their rights on an equal basis with others. These include support to access information, exercise legal capacity, prevent and report violence, ensure personal mobility, participate in education and employment, and engage fully in community and public life.

The proposal also emphasizes the central role of personal assistance and community-based services, such as centers for independent living, to prevent institutionalization and forced dependence on families.

Diana Velarde, executive director of Mexicanas con Discapacidad and a member of the coalition, said the proposal reflects what people with disabilities have long demanded in their daily lives. “For many of us, support is not an abstract legal concept—it is what makes it possible to leave our homes, participate in our communities, and live with dignity,” Velarde said. “This proposal puts into law what international standards already recognize: that care and support are rights, and that states have an obligation to ensure they are available, accessible, and centered on people’s autonomy.”

Coalition members also emphasized the often invisible costs of relying on unpaid family care and support. Sara Villanueva, a member of the coalition who requires intensive support, said the absence of adequate public systems places an unsustainable responsibility on families, particularly as the parents of people with disabilities grow older.

“In many cases, the support that allows us to live day to day is provided by our families, without pay, without rest, and without alternatives,” Villanueva said. “My parents—both in their 80s—continue to provide essential support so that I can live my life. This is not a solution that can last forever.”

Villanueva emphasized that the proposal is especially significant because it reflects the realities of people with disabilities themselves. “This coalition is made up almost entirely of people with disabilities, most of us women,” she said. “Our proposal responds to real needs and real barriers, not assumptions about our lives.”

“Aligning care and support policies with international human rights standards is both possible and effective to ensure rights for care and support providers and people with disabilities,” Ríos Espinosa said. “Mexico City has an opportunity to ensure that its legislative proposals on care and support are consistent with these standards and recognize supports for independent living as a core component of equality and dignity for people with disabilities.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant legislative proposal in Mexico City led by a coalition of people with disabilities and human rights organizations to establish a rights-based care and support law. This proposal emphasizes autonomy, participation, and independent living, aligning with international human rights standards, and aims to improve the quality of life and equality for people with disabilities on a broad societal scale. The story has clear substance, real-world impact, and meaningful scope for the general public.
articles.personality_title: Mexico City coalition pushes for disability rights in new care law
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Mexico City is working on new laws about care and support for people who need help in daily life. Right now, these laws often focus on charity, which can make people feel dependent instead of independent.

**What happened** – A group called Cuidados Sí; Apoyos También (Care Yes; Supports Too), mostly made up of people with disabilities and human rights groups, sent a proposal to Mexico City's Congress. They want the new care law to focus on rights like independence, choice, and community participation. The proposal asks lawmakers to include a special chapter about helping people live independently.

**Impact** – This proposal is important because it comes directly from people with disabilities who know what support they really need. It moves away from old ideas that treat care as a favor and instead treats it as a right. It also points out problems with relying only on family members for support, which can be very hard on families, especially as they get older.

**What's next step** – Mexico City Congress will review this proposal as they write the new care and support law. If they accept it, the city could create a law that helps people with disabilities live more independently and with dignity, following international human rights standards.

**One-sentence takeaway** – People with disabilities in Mexico City are leading a new proposal to make care and support laws that respect their independence and rights.
articles.personality_title_fr: Mexico City : une coalition pour une loi sur les droits des personnes handicapées
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Mexico travaille sur de nouvelles lois concernant les soins et le soutien pour les personnes qui ont besoin d’aide au quotidien. Actuellement, ces lois sont souvent basées sur la charité, ce qui peut rendre les personnes dépendantes au lieu d’indépendantes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Un groupe nommé Cuidados Sí; Apoyos También (Soins Oui; Soutiens Aussi), composé principalement de personnes handicapées et d’organisations de défense des droits humains, a soumis une proposition au Congrès de Mexico. Ils souhaitent que la nouvelle loi sur les soins mette l’accent sur les droits comme l’indépendance, le choix et la participation dans la communauté. La proposition demande une partie spéciale sur le soutien à la vie indépendante.

**Impact** – Cette proposition est importante car elle vient directement des personnes handicapées qui savent quel soutien elles ont vraiment besoin. Elle s’éloigne des anciennes idées qui considèrent les soins comme une faveur et les traite comme un droit. Elle souligne aussi les difficultés liées au fait de compter uniquement sur la famille pour le soutien, ce qui peut être très lourd, surtout avec l’âge.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Congrès de Mexico va examiner cette proposition en rédigeant la nouvelle loi sur les soins et le soutien. S’ils l’acceptent, la ville pourrait créer une loi qui aide les personnes handicapées à vivre plus indépendamment et dignement, en suivant les normes internationales des droits humains.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Les personnes handicapées de Mexico dirigent une nouvelle proposition pour que les lois sur les soins respectent leur indépendance et leurs droits.
articles.personality_title_es: Ciudad de México impulsa ley de cuidados basada en derechos de personas con discapacidad
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Ciudad de México está trabajando en nuevas leyes sobre cuidados y apoyos para personas que necesitan ayuda en su vida diaria. Actualmente, estas leyes suelen centrarse en la caridad, lo que puede hacer que las personas se sientan dependientes en lugar de independientes.

**Qué pasó** – Un grupo llamado Cuidados Sí; Apoyos También, formado principalmente por personas con discapacidad y organizaciones de derechos humanos, presentó una propuesta al Congreso de la Ciudad de México. Quieren que la nueva ley de cuidados se enfoque en derechos como la independencia, la participación y la vida comunitaria. La propuesta pide incluir un capítulo especial sobre apoyo para la vida independiente.

**Impacto** – Esta propuesta es importante porque viene directamente de personas con discapacidad que conocen las necesidades reales de apoyo. Se aleja de ideas antiguas que ven el cuidado como un favor y lo trata como un derecho. También señala los problemas que surgen al depender solo de los familiares para el apoyo, algo muy difícil especialmente cuando los familiares envejecen.

**Próximo paso** – El Congreso de Ciudad de México revisará esta propuesta mientras redacta la nueva ley de cuidados y apoyos. Si la aceptan, la ciudad podría crear una ley que ayude a las personas con discapacidad a vivir con más independencia y dignidad, siguiendo normas internacionales de derechos humanos.

**Frase clave** – Personas con discapacidad en Ciudad de México lideran una propuesta para que las leyes de cuidados respeten su independencia y derechos.

articles.title: Press release - Parliament approves €90 billion Ukraine support loan package
articles.summary: MEPs voted in favour of three pieces of legislation to make a €90 billion EU loan available for Ukraine as it faces Russia’s continued war of aggression.Committee on Foreign AffairsCommittee on BudgetsCommittee on International TradeCommittee on Security and Defence Source : © European Union, 2026 - EP
articles.content:
On Wednesday Parliament adopted a package of proposals aimed at supporting Ukraine with a €90 billion EU loan for 2026 and 2027. The so-called Ukraine support loan will help meet Ukraine’s urgent financing needs amid Russia’s ongoing war of aggression entering its fifth year.

Of the loan, €30 billion will be made available for macro-financial assistance or budget support, delivered through the EU’s Ukraine Facility. €60 billion will be allocated to strengthen Ukraine’s defence capabilities and support the procurement of military equipment, ensuring timely access to critical defence products from - in principle - Ukrainian, EU, and European Economic Area (EEA)/European Free Trade Association (EFTA) defence industries. If certain defence material is not immediately available from these countries for urgent delivery to Ukraine, a set of targeted derogations will apply to sourcing them from other countries.

Financial assistance will be provided in line with Ukraine’s financing needs, as set out in a financing strategy prepared by Ukraine and assessed by the Commission. The strategy will require approval by the Council.

All funding will be subject to strict conditions, including Ukraine’s continued commitment to democratic governance, the rule of law, and the protection of human rights, including the rights of minorities. This includes ongoing efforts to combat corruption and strengthen democratic institutions.

The support loan will be financed through common EU borrowing from capital markets and guaranteed by the “headroom” of the EU long-term budget, and debt-servicing costs will be covered by the EU’s annual budgets. The Commission has estimated the debt service costs at around €1 billion for 2027 and around €3 billion per year from 2028. Ukraine will be liable for the repayment of the principal of the loan once it receives war reparations from Russia.

The legislative acts needed to complete this support package were adopted under the Parliament’s urgent procedure to ensure the provision of rapid aid to Ukraine. The proposal on the Ukraine support loan was approved with 458 votes to 140 and 44 abstentions, the proposal to amend the Ukraine Facility received 473 votes to 140, and 32 abstentions, while the proposal to amend the 2021-2027 EU long-term budget (MFF) secured 490 votes to 130 and 32 abstentions.

Next steps

The Council also needs to formally adopt the package in order for the Commission to be able to disburse the first payment early in the second quarter of 2026.

Background

The EU support loan was agreed at the European Council in Brussels on 18 December 2025, and presented by the European Commission on 14 January 2026. The €90 billion is intended to cover two-thirds of Ukraine’s estimated financial needs for the period concerned. As Czechia, Hungary and Slovakia have opted out from backing the loan, the agreement was taken under the enhanced cooperation procedure, a mechanism that allows willing EU member states to collaborate in specific areas absent unanimity.
articles.reasoning: The EU Parliament's approval of a €90 billion loan package to support Ukraine amid ongoing war represents a significant humanitarian and political commitment. It provides substantial financial and defense aid to help Ukraine maintain sovereignty, democratic governance, and human rights protections during a critical conflict. The scale and scope of the support have broad implications for European stability and uphold democratic values, meeting the criteria for inspiring good news.
articles.personality_title: EU Parliament approves €90 billion loan to support Ukraine during war
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Ukraine has been facing a war with Russia that started almost five years ago. The European Union (EU) wants to help Ukraine by providing financial and defense support.

**What happened** – On Wednesday, the EU Parliament voted to approve a €90 billion loan package for Ukraine covering 2026 and 2027. This money will help Ukraine with urgent needs during the war. Of the €90 billion, €30 billion will support Ukraine’s government budget, and €60 billion will be used to buy military equipment and strengthen Ukraine’s defense.

**Impact** – This loan is important because it helps Ukraine keep its government running and defend itself. The money comes with conditions that Ukraine must keep protecting democracy, human rights, and fight corruption. The loan is funded by the EU borrowing money, and Ukraine will repay it once it receives war damages from Russia. This support shows strong cooperation among EU countries willing to help, even though some chose not to join.

**What's next step** – The EU Council still needs to formally approve the loan package. After that, the European Commission can start sending the first payments to Ukraine early in the second quarter of 2026.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU Parliament’s approval of a €90 billion loan offers crucial financial and defense aid to help Ukraine during its ongoing conflict with Russia.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Parlement européen approuve un prêt de 90 milliards d'euros pour soutenir l'Ukraine en guerre
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Ukraine fait face à une guerre avec la Russie depuis presque cinq ans. L’Union européenne (UE) souhaite aider l’Ukraine en lui fournissant un soutien financier et militaire.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Mercredi, le Parlement européen a voté pour approuver un prêt de 90 milliards d’euros destiné à l’Ukraine pour les années 2026 et 2027. Cette somme aidera l’Ukraine à répondre à ses besoins urgents pendant la guerre. Sur les 90 milliards, 30 milliards iront au budget du gouvernement ukrainien, et 60 milliards serviront à acheter du matériel militaire et renforcer la défense.

**Impact** – Ce prêt est important car il aide l’Ukraine à faire fonctionner son gouvernement et à se défendre. L’argent est donné à condition que l’Ukraine continue à protéger la démocratie, les droits humains et lutte contre la corruption. Le prêt est financé par l’UE qui emprunte de l’argent, et l’Ukraine remboursera quand elle recevra des réparations de guerre de la Russie. Ce soutien montre une forte coopération entre les pays de l’UE prêts à aider, même si certains ont choisi de ne pas participer.

**Prochaines étapes** – Le Conseil de l’UE doit encore approuver officiellement le prêt. Ensuite, la Commission européenne pourra commencer à verser les premiers paiements à l’Ukraine au début du deuxième trimestre 2026.

**En une phrase** – L’approbation par le Parlement européen d’un prêt de 90 milliards d’euros offre une aide financière et militaire essentielle à l’Ukraine pendant son conflit en cours avec la Russie.
articles.personality_title_es: El Parlamento de la UE aprueba un préstamo de 90.000 millones de euros para apoyar a Ucrania durante la guerra
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Ucrania enfrenta una guerra con Rusia que comenzó hace casi cinco años. La Unión Europea (UE) quiere ayudar a Ucrania proporcionando apoyo financiero y militar.

**Qué pasó** – El miércoles, el Parlamento de la UE aprobó un paquete de préstamo de 90.000 millones de euros para Ucrania para 2026 y 2027. Este dinero ayudará a Ucrania con necesidades urgentes durante la guerra. De los 90.000 millones, 30.000 millones apoyarán el presupuesto del gobierno ucraniano y 60.000 millones se usarán para comprar equipo militar y fortalecer la defensa.

**Impacto** – Este préstamo es importante porque ayuda a Ucrania a mantener su gobierno y defenderse. El dinero viene con condiciones para que Ucrania siga protegiendo la democracia, los derechos humanos y combatiendo la corrupción. El préstamo se financia con dinero que la UE pide prestado, y Ucrania lo devolverá cuando reciba reparaciones de guerra de Rusia. Este apoyo muestra una fuerte cooperación entre los países de la UE dispuestos a ayudar, aunque algunos decidieron no participar.

**Próximo paso** – El Consejo de la UE todavía debe aprobar formalmente el paquete de préstamo. Luego, la Comisión Europea podrá comenzar a enviar los primeros pagos a Ucrania a principios del segundo trimestre de 2026.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La aprobación del Parlamento de la UE de un préstamo de 90.000 millones de euros ofrece ayuda financiera y militar crucial para apoyar a Ucrania durante su conflicto con Rusia.

articles.title: Gaza radio station re-opens, bringing voices from the rubble
articles.summary: Broadcaster Rami Al-Sharafi works on a laptop inside the damaged Zaman FM radio station building in Gaza, marking what may seem an unlikely return to the airwaves amid the rubble of the deadly two-year Israel-Hamas war.
articles.content:
While 23 local radio stations were operating in Gaza before the conflict erupted, they were all destroyed and ceased broadcasting, he told UN News.

“Today, we are the only radio station broadcasting on FM from within Gaza after this widespread destruction,” he said. “We hope that other local radio stations will resume broadcasting, thus allowing competition in providing media services to the people of the Gaza Strip.”

Ahead of World Radio Day, observed on 13 February, the resumption of broadcasting comes at a time when Gaza’s media infrastructure still faces significant challenges amid local and international calls to support journalism as part of broader recovery and reconstruction efforts in the sector.

UN News A journalist works in the damaged office of Zaman 90.60 FM radio station in Gaza City.

Digging through the rubble

After a hiatus of nearly two years due to the war, some local radio stations in the Gaza Strip are transmitting again, in a move showing gradual efforts to revive the media landscape in the war-ravaged Strip – much of which has suffered widespread destruction of infrastructure and civilian institutions from Israeli attacks.

Zaman FM operates in the Tel al-Hawa neighbourhood of Gaza City, where Israeli attacks triggered a famine and left mountains of debris in the streets.

The cracked walls of the station’s building tell a story of immense destruction and the scene inside is unlike any other radio studio in the world.

Employees dig through the rubble to keep the station broadcasting, working with minimal technical resources while behind them, awareness posters warn people of the dangers of dilapidated buildings.

On-air messages of hope

Local radio remains vital in Gaza as humanitarian crises persist, power outages continue and access to other media remains limited. This makes radio one of the most effective ways of getting key messages out to the public, along with health guidance and information about other services.

Gaza is in dire need of professional local radio stations capable of broadcasting awareness messages and guidance bulletins in light of the spread of diseases, the deterioration of the education system and the disruption of many basic services, said Mr. Al-Sharafi, director of the radio station and host of the morning programme, An Hour of Time.

“We need to deliver information to the population and guide them to the services that have stopped and are gradually being resumed,” he said, “especially in light of the difficult health conditions and the spread of epidemics.”

Amid the destruction all around, Mr. Al-Sharafi sits behind his dust-covered microphone and does just that.

He sends morning greetings to Gaza residents and provides them with important information and updates, bringing some much-needed hope to the airwaves across a devastated landscape that has only just begun to recover.
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories
articles.reasoning: The article reports the inspiring reopening of a local radio station in Gaza after widespread destruction from war, restoring a vital communication channel for the population. This has broad significance as it supports public information dissemination, health guidance, and community resilience amid ongoing humanitarian crises, representing meaningful recovery and hope for many people.
articles.personality_title: Gaza radio station restarts amid war damage to share vital news
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Before the recent war in Gaza, 23 local radio stations were working to provide news and information to the people. However, the conflict caused heavy damage, destroying all these stations and stopping their broadcasts.

**What happened** – After nearly two years, Zaman FM, a radio station in Gaza City, has reopened and started broadcasting again. The station operates from a damaged building where staff work among rubble and broken walls, using limited equipment to keep the station on air.

**Impact** – This reopening is important because radio is one of the few ways people in Gaza can get reliable information during ongoing power outages and difficult living conditions. The station shares news, health advice, and updates about local services, helping people stay informed and safe amid the challenges.

**What's next step** – The station hopes other local radio stations in Gaza will also restart soon, bringing more voices and competition to improve media services. This could support the recovery of Gaza’s media and help people access more information as rebuilding continues.

**One-sentence takeaway** – After war destruction, Zaman FM’s return to the airwaves brings crucial news and hope to Gaza’s people in difficult times.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une station de radio de Gaza reprend ses émissions malgré les dégâts de la guerre
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Avant la récente guerre à Gaza, 23 stations de radio locales offraient des informations aux habitants. Mais le conflit a causé de lourds dégâts, détruisant toutes ces stations et arrêtant leurs émissions.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Après presque deux ans, Zaman FM, une station de radio à Gaza, a rouvert et recommencé à émettre. La station fonctionne dans un bâtiment endommagé où le personnel travaille parmi les décombres et les murs cassés, avec peu de matériel.

**Impact** – Cette réouverture est importante car la radio est l’un des rares moyens pour les habitants de Gaza d’obtenir des informations fiables malgré les coupures de courant et les conditions difficiles. La station diffuse des nouvelles, des conseils de santé et des mises à jour sur les services locaux, aidant les gens à rester informés et en sécurité.

**Prochaine étape** – La station espère que d’autres radios locales à Gaza reprendront aussi bientôt, apportant plus de voix et de concurrence pour améliorer les services médiatiques. Cela pourrait soutenir la reconstruction des médias à Gaza et permettre un meilleur accès à l’information.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Après la destruction due à la guerre, le retour de Zaman FM sur les ondes apporte des informations essentielles et de l’espoir au peuple de Gaza en ces temps difficiles.
articles.personality_title_es: Estación de radio de Gaza reabre tras daños de guerra para compartir noticias vitales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Antes de la reciente guerra en Gaza, 23 estaciones de radio locales funcionaban para informar a la población. Sin embargo, el conflicto causó graves daños, destruyendo todas estas estaciones y deteniendo sus transmisiones.

**Impacto** – Esta reapertura es importante porque la radio es una de las pocas formas en que las personas en Gaza pueden obtener información confiable durante cortes de energía y condiciones difíciles. La estación comparte noticias, consejos de salud y actualizaciones sobre servicios locales, ayudando a la gente a mantenerse informada y segura.

**Próximo paso** – La estación espera que otras radios locales en Gaza también reanuden pronto sus transmisiones, trayendo más voces y competencia para mejorar los servicios de medios. Esto podría apoyar la recuperación de los medios en Gaza y ayudar a las personas a acceder a más información mientras continúa la reconstrucción.

articles.title: Press release - MEPs back €7.5 million in EU support for workers in Belgium
articles.summary: Parliament gave its green light for EU funds to be disbursed for workers dismissed following the closure of an Audi factory in Brussels.Committee on Budgets Source : © European Union, 2026 - EP
articles.content:
On Wednesday, MEPs backed the release of €7.5 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Displaced Workers (EGF) to assist 3,414 workers who lost their jobs after the carmaker Audi closed its Brussels facility. The decision was adopted in plenary by 593 votes in favour, 55 against and 9 abstentions.

In February 2025, Audi halted production of its Q8 e-tron model in Brussels and shuttered the plant after over 75 years activity, triggering layoffs not only at Audi itself but also among several of its suppliers. The EGF support is expected to benefit 2,580 former Audi employees and 834 workers from supplier firms. EU-funded measures will include career guidance, job-search assistance, training in new skills, and support for workers wishing to set up their own businesses.
